# ::snt-type date [signifies start of new document]

# ::id 56d7d67b.1 ::snt-type summary
# ::tok Navarrette : Opponents see Hispanic immigrants as weakening U.S. identity .
# ::alignments 3-1.2 5-1.2.2 5-1.2.2.1.r 5-1.2.2.1 7-1.2.3 9-1.2.3.2 
# ::snt Navarrette: Opponents see Hispanic immigrants as weakening U.S. identity .
(s / say-01
      :ARG0 (p / person
            :name (n / name
                  :op1 "Navarrette"))
      :ARG1 (s2 / see-01
            :ARG0 (p2 / person
                  :ARG0-of (o / oppose-01))
            :ARG1 (p3 / person
                  :ARG0-of (ii / immigrate-01)
                  :mod (e / ethnic-group
                        :name (n2 / name
                              :op1 "Hispanic")))
            :ARG2 (w / weaken-01
                  :ARG0 p3
                  :ARG1 (ii2 / identity
                        :mod (c / country
                              :name (n3 / name
                                    :op1 "U.S."))))))

# ::id 56d7d67b.2 ::snt-type summary

      :ARG0 (p / person

                  :quant 1)
            :ARG1 (b / book
                  :mod (l / library)
                  :mod (a / all)
                  :medium (l2 / language
                        :name (n2 / name
                              :op1 "English")))))

# ::id 56d7d67b.7 ::snt-type body

(l / like-01
      :ARG0 (p / person
            :ARG0-of (r / restrict-01
                  :ARG1 (ii / immigrate-01))
            :ARG1-of (m / mean-01
                  :ARG0 (ii2 / i)
                  :ARG2 (p2 / person
                        :ARG0-of (w / want-01
                              :ARG1 (l2 / limit-01
                                    :ARG0 p2
                                    :ARG1 (a / and
                                          :op1 (ii3 / immigrate-01
                                                :mod (a2 / all))
                                          :op2 (ii4 / immigrate-01
                                                :mod (k / kind
                                                      :ARG1-of (l3 / legal-02)
                                                      :mod (e / even)))))))))
      :ARG1 (p3 / pretend-01
            :ARG0 p
            :ARG1 (h / have-degree-91
                  :ARG1 p
                  :ARG2 (h2 / high-minded)
                  :ARG3 (s / so))))

# ::id 56d7d67b.10 ::snt-type body
# ::tok The restrictionists insist that what bothers them are merely practical concerns : that our borders are n't secure , that so many immigrants are coming into the country illegally , and that the new arrivals are burdening schools and draining social services once they get here .
# ::alignments 2-1 1-1.1 1-1.1.1.r 1-1.1.1 4-1.2 5-1.2.1.r 5-1.2.1 9-1.2.2 17-1.2.3.1 16-1.2.3.1.1.r 16-1.2.3.1.1 14-1.2.3.1.2 45-1.2.3.1.2.1.r 13-1.2.3.1.2.1 24-1.2.3.2 22-1.2.3.2.1 22-1.2.3.2.1.1.r 22-1.2.3.2.1.1 21-1.2.3.2.1.2.1 20-1.2.3.2.1.2.2 27-1.2.3.2.2 28-1.2.3.2.3 30-1.2.3.3 36-1.2.3.3.1 34-1.2.3.3.1.1 34-1.2.3.3.1.1.1.r 34-1.2.3.3.1.1.1 33-1.2.3.3.1.1.1.1 37-1.2.3.3.1.2 39-1.2.3.3.2 41-1.2.3.3.2.2 40-1.2.3.3.2.2.1 44-1.2.3.3.3 8-1.2.4 
# ::snt The restrictionists insist that what bothers them are merely practical concerns: that our borders aren't secure, that so many immigrants are coming into the country illegally, and that the new arrivals are burdening schools and draining social services once they get here.
(ii / insist-01
      :ARG0 (p / person
            :ARG0-of (r / restrict-01))
      :ARG1 (t / thing
            :ARG0-of (b / bother-01
                  :ARG1 p)
            :ARG1-of (p2 / practical-02)
            :domain (a / and
                  :op1 (s / secure-02
                        :polarity -
                        :ARG1 (b2 / border
                              :poss (w / we)))
                  :op2 (c / come-01
                        :ARG1 (p3 / person
                              :ARG0-of (ii2 / immigrate-01)
                              :ARG1-of (h / have-quant-91
                                    :ARG2 (m / many)
                                    :ARG3 (s2 / so)))
                        :ARG4 (c2 / country)
                        :ARG1-of (l / legal-02
                              :polarity -))
                  :op3 (a2 / and
                        :op1 (b3 / burden-01
                              :ARG0 (p4 / person
                                    :ARG1-of (a3 / arrive-01
                                          :ARG1-of (n / new-01)))
                              :ARG1 (s3 / school))
                        :op2 (d / drain-01
                              :ARG0 p4
                              :ARG1 (s4 / service
                                    :mod (s5 / society)))
                        :time (g / get-05
                              :ARG1 p4
                              :ARG2 c2)))
            :mod (m2 / mere)))

# ::id 56d7d67b.12 ::snt-type body
# ::tok If that 's the extent of it , then why does the conversation quickly turn to the impact -- both real and perceived -- that immigrants have on American culture through everything from taco trucks to Spanish-language billboards .
# ::alignments 14-1 12-1.1 17-1.2 25-1.2.1 25-1.2.1.1.r 25-1.2.1.1 29-1.2.2 20-1.2.3 22-1.2.4 30-1.2.5.r 31-1.2.5 5-1.2.5.1 21-1.2.5.1.1 34-1.2.5.1.1.1 33-1.2.5.1.1.1.1 37-1.2.5.1.1.2 13-1.3 9-1.4 9-1.4.1 10-1.4.1 4-1.5 1-1.5.1 24-1.5.1 2-1.5.2.r 6-1.5.2 
# ::snt If that's the extent of it, then why does the conversation quickly turn to the impact -- both real and perceived -- that immigrants have on American culture through everything from taco trucks to Spanish-language billboards.
(t / turn-01
      :ARG1 (c / converse-01)
      :direction (ii / impact-01
            :ARG0 (p / person
                  :ARG0-of (ii2 / immigrate-01))
            :ARG1 (c2 / culture
                  :mod (c3 / country
                        :name (n / name
                              :op1 "America")))
            :ARG1-of (r / real-04)
            :ARG1-of (p2 / perceive-01)
            :medium (e / everything
                  :ARG2-of (ii3 / include-91
                        :ARG1 (a / and
                              :op1 (t2 / truck
                                    :mod (t3 / taco))
                              :op2 (b / billboard
                                    :mod (l / language
                                          :name (n2 / name
                                                :op1 "Spanish")))))))
      :ARG1-of (q / quick-02)
      :ARG1-of (c4 / cause-01
            :ARG0 (a2 / amr-unknown))
      :condition (e2 / extent
            :domain (t4 / that)
            :poss (ii4 / it)))

      :ARG1 (ii / issue-02

            :ARG1 (s2 / state
                  :name (n / name
                        :op1 "North"
                        :op2 "Dakota")
                  :location-of (r / resist-01
                        :ARG0 (t2 / town
                              :ARG0-of (f / face-01
                                    :ARG1 (t3 / time
                                          :ARG1-of (t4 / tough-02)
                                          :mod (e / economy))))
                        :ARG1 (t5 / transfuse-01
                              :ARG1 (c / culture)
                              :ARG0-of (s3 / save-02
                                    :ARG1 t2
                                    :ARG1-of (p / possible-01)))
                        :ARG1-of (h / have-concession-91)
                        :ARG1-of (s4 / say-01
                              :ARG0 (a / article
                                    :time (r2 / recent)
                                    :source (n2 / newspaper
                                          :name (n3 / name
                                                :op1 "USA"
                                                :op2 "Today"))))))))

# ::snt In Cooperstown, the locals opposed efforts to bring in a hog plant and a dairy, because those kind of dirty and hard jobs are likely to attract ... guess who?

      :ARG0 (p / person
            :ARG1-of (l / local-02))
      :ARG1 (e / effort-01
            :ARG1 (b / bring-01
                  :ARG1 (a / and
                        :op1 (p2 / plant
                              :mod (h / hog))
                        :op2 (d / dairy))))
      :location (c / city
            :name (n / name
                  :op1 "Cooperstown"))
      :ARG1-of (c2 / cause-01
            :ARG0 (l2 / likely-01
                  :ARG1 (a2 / attract-01
                        :ARG0 (j / job
                              :ARG1-of (d2 / dirty-02)
                              :ARG1-of (h2 / hard-02)
                              :mod (k / kind
                                    :mod (t / that))))))
      :ARG1-of (g / guess-01
            :mode imperative
            :ARG0 (y / you)))

# ::alignments 2-1 1-1.1 9-1.2.2 8-1.2.2.1 7-1.2.2.1.1 10-1.2.2.2.r 14-1.2.3 19-1.2.3.1 17-1.2.3.1.1 17-1.2.3.1.1.1.r 17-1.2.3.1.1.1 16-1.2.3.1.1.2 29-1.2.3.1.2 30-1.2.3.1.2.1 22-1.2.3.1.2.1.1 28-1.2.3.1.2.1.1 27-1.2.3.1.2.1.1.1 32-1.2.3.1.2.1.2 32-1.2.3.1.2.1.2.1.r 32-1.2.3.1.2.1.2.1 32-1.2.3.1.2.1.2.3.r 35-1.2.3.1.2.1.2.3 38-1.2.3.1.2.1.2.3.1 37-1.2.3.1.2.1.2.3.1.1 29-1.2.3.1.2.1.2.3.2

      :ARG2 (p / person
            :name (n / name
                  :op1 "Orville"
                  :op2 "Tranby")
            :ARG0-of (l / lead-02
                  :ARG1 (c / community
                        :ARG1-of (l2 / local-02))
                  :location (c2 / city
                        :name (n2 / name
                              :op1 "Cooperstown")))
            :ARG0-of (s / say-01
                  :ARG1 (t / tell-01
                        :ARG0 (p2 / person
                              :ARG0-of (r / reside-01)
                              :mod (s2 / some))
                        :ARG1 (p3 / possible-01
                              :ARG1 (a2 / attract-01
                                    :ARG0 (f / facility
                                          :mod (s3 / such))
                                    :ARG1 (p4 / person
                                          :ARG0-of (ii / immigrate-01)
                                          :mod (e / ethnic-group
                                                :name (n3 / name
                                                      :op1 "Hispanic"))
                                          :ARG0-of (c3 / change-01
                                                :ARG1 (c4 / culture
                                                      :ARG1-of (l3 / local-02))
                                                :ARG1-of (p5 / possible-01)))))

                        :manner (f2 / face-to-face)))))

# ::id 56d7d67b.23 ::snt-type body
# ::tok They illustrate what some people are really concerned about with immigration , and it goes well beyond words like `` legal '' or `` illegal . ''
# ::alignments 12-1 1-1.1 2-1.1.2 7-1.1.2.1.r 7-1.1.2.1 4-1.1.2.1.1 3-1.1.2.1.1.1 13-1.1.2.1.2.r 6-1.1.2.1.2 8-1.1.2.1.3.r 10-1.1.2.1.3 14-1.2 16-1.2.2 17-1.2.2.1 18-1.2.2.1.1.r 22-1.2.2.1.1 20-1.2.2.1.1.1 20-1.2.2.1.1.2 24-1.2.2.1.1.2.1.r 15-1.2.2.2 
# ::snt They illustrate what some people are really concerned about with immigration, and it goes well beyond words like "legal" or "illegal."
(a / and
      :op1 (ii / illustrate-01
            :ARG0 (t / they)
            :ARG1 (t2 / thing
                  :ARG0-of (c / concern-01
                        :ARG1 (p / person
                              :mod (s / some))
                        :degree (r / really)
                        :topic (ii2 / immigrate-01))))
      :op2 (g / go-01
            :ARG1 t2
            :ARG4 (b / beyond
                  :op1 (w / word
                        :example (o / or
                              :op1 (l / legal-02)
                              :op2 (l2 / legal-02
                                    :polarity -)))
                  :degree (w2 / well))))

# ::id 56d7d67b.24 ::snt-type body
# ::tok It 's the perception that the country is becoming more Hispanic , that Spanish is replacing English , that Hispanic immigrants are weakening American identity , and that Main Street is turning into Little Mexico .
# ::alignments 3-1 26-1.1 8-1.1.1 6-1.1.1.1 9-1.1.1.2.3 15-1.1.2 22-1.1.3 20-1.1.3.1 20-1.1.3.1.1.r 20-1.1.3.1.1 24-1.1.3.2 1-1.1.3.2.1.r 31-1.1.4 
# ::snt It's the perception that the country is becoming more Hispanic, that Spanish is replacing English, that Hispanic immigrants are weakening American identity, and that Main Street is turning into Little Mexico.
(p / perceive-01
      :ARG1 (a / and
            :op1 (b / become-01
                  :ARG1 (c / country)
                  :ARG2 (h / have-degree-91
                        :ARG1 c
                        :ARG2 (e / ethnic-group
                              :name (n / name
                                    :op1 "Hispanic"))
                        :ARG3 (m / more)))
            :op2 (r / replace-01
                  :ARG1 (p2 / person
                        :mod (c2 / country
                              :name (n2 / name
                                    :op1 "England")))
                  :ARG2 (p3 / person
                        :mod (l / language
                              :name (n3 / name
                                    :op1 "Spanish"))))
            :op3 (w / weaken-01
                  :ARG0 (p4 / person
                        :ARG0-of (ii / immigrate-01
                              :ARG2 (c3 / country
                                    :name (n4 / name
                                          :op1 "America")))
                        :mod e)
                  :ARG1 (ii2 / identity
                        :poss c3))
            :op4 (t / turn-02
                  :ARG1 (m2 / Main-Street)
                  :ARG2 (c4 / country-region
                        :name (n5 / name
                              :op1 "Little"
                              :op2 "Mexico")))))

# ::snt This sort of rhetoric is all about fear -- that those who thrive in the dominant culture are losing their primacy, that the mainstream is being polluted by foreigners, and that our children are going to live in a world where they're going to have to work a lot harder to keep up.

                  :mod (t / this)))

            :ARG1 (a / and
                  :op1 (l / lose-02
                        :ARG0 (p / person
                              :ARG0-of (t2 / thrive-01
                                    :location (c2 / culture
                                          :ARG0-of (d / dominate-01)))
                              :mod (t3 / that))
                        :ARG1 (s2 / supremacy
                              :poss p))
                  :op2 (p2 / pollute-01
                        :ARG0 (p3 / person
                              :mod (f2 / foreign))
                        :ARG1 (m / mainstream))
                  :op3 (l2 / live-01
                        :ARG0 (p4 / person
                              :ARG0-of (h / have-rel-role-91

                        :location (w2 / world
                              :location-of (o / obligate-01
                                    :ARG1 p4

                                          :ARG0 p4

                                                      :ARG1 w3)
                                                :ARG3 (m2 / more
                                                      :quant (l3 / lot)))
                                          :purpose (k / keep-up-05
                                                :ARG0 p4))))))))

# ::id 56d7d67b.27 ::snt-type body
# ::tok It conjures up the alarm bells that Benjamin Franklin set off about German immigrants in the late 18th century , who he insisted could never adopt the culture of the English , but would `` swarm into our Settlements , and by herding together establish their Language and Manners to the Exclusion of ours . ''
# ::alignments 1-1 5-1.2 4-1.2.1 9-1.2.2 16-1.2.2.2 18-1.2.2.2.1.1.r 17-1.2.2.2.1.1 11-1.2.3.r 13-1.2.3 13-1.2.3.1.r 13-1.2.3.1 13-1.2.3.3.r 25-1.2.3.3 24-1.2.3.3.1.r 24-1.2.3.3.1 27-1.2.3.3.2 22-1.2.3.3.4 35-1.2.3.3.5.1 36-1.2.3.3.5.1.2.r 37-1.2.3.3.5.1.2.1 44-1.2.3.3.5.2 40-1.2.3.3.5.2.2 42-1.2.3.3.5.2.3 43-1.2.3.3.5.2.3.3 49-1.2.3.3.5.2.4.r 
# ::snt It conjures up the alarm bells that Benjamin Franklin set off about German immigrants in the late 18th century, who he insisted could never adopt the culture of the English, but would "swarm into our Settlements, and by herding together establish their Language and Manners to the Exclusion of ours."
(c / conjure-up-02
      :ARG0 (ii / it)
      :ARG1 (b / bell
            :ARG0-of (a / alarm-01)
            :ARG1-of (s / set-off-04
                  :ARG0 (p / person
                        :name (n / name
                              :op1 "Benjamin"
                              :op2 "Franklin"))
                  :time (l / late
                        :op1 (d / date-entity
                              :century 18)))
            :topic (p2 / person
                  :ARG0-of (ii2 / immigrate-01)
                  :mod (c2 / country
                        :name (n2 / name
                              :op1 "Germany"))
                  :ARG0-of (a2 / adopt-01
                        :polarity -
                        :ARG1 (c3 / culture
                              :poss (p3 / person
                                    :mod (c4 / country
                                          :name (n3 / name
                                                :op1 "England"))))
                        :time (e / ever)
                        :ARG1-of (ii3 / insist-01
                              :ARG0 p)
                        :ARG1-of (c5 / contrast-01
                              :ARG2 (s2 / swarm-01
                                    :ARG0 p2
                                    :destination (s3 / settlement
                                          :poss (w / we)))
                              :manner (e2 / establish-01
                                    :ARG0 p2
                                    :ARG1 (a3 / and
                                          :op1 (l2 / language
                                                :poss p2)
                                          :op2 (m / manners
                                                :poss p2))
                                    :manner (h / herd-01
                                          :ARG0 p2
                                          :ARG1 p2
                                          :mod (t / together))
                                    :prep-to (e3 / exclude-01
                                          :ARG1 a3
                                          :ARG2 (s4 / settlement
                                                :poss w))))))))

# ::id 73818f6c.4 ::snt-type body
# ::tok In the days after Benazir Bhutto 's assassination , it will be tempting to reach two hasty conclusions : that she was Pakistan 's last great hope and that her geo-politically crucial country has revealed itself to be inherently hopeless .
# ::alignments 12-1 14-1.1 17-1.1.1 15-1.1.1.1 27-1.1.1.2 26-1.1.1.2.1 25-1.1.1.2.1.3 34-1.1.1.2.2 32-1.1.1.2.2.1 31-1.1.1.2.2.1.1 30-1.1.1.2.2.1.2 29-1.1.1.2.2.1.3.r 35-1.1.1.2.2.1.3.r 26-1.1.1.2.2.2 39-1.1.1.2.2.2 38-1.1.1.2.2.2.1 9-1.1.1.2.2.2.2.r 33-1.1.1.3 3-1.2 7-1.2.1 2-1.2.2.1.2 
# ::snt In the days after Benazir Bhutto's assassination, it will be tempting to reach two hasty conclusions: that she was Pakistan's last great hope and that her geo-politically crucial country has revealed itself to be  inherently hopeless.

      :ARG0 (r / reach-01

                  :quant 2
                  :ARG1 (a / and
                        :op1 (h / hopeful-03
                              :ARG0 (c2 / country
                                    :name (n / name
                                          :op1 "Pakistan"))
                              :ARG1 (p / person
                                    :name (n2 / name
                                          :op1 "Benazir"
                                          :op2 "Bhutto"))
                              :mod (g / great)
                              :ord (o / ordinal-entity
                                    :value -1))
                        :op2 (r2 / reveal-01
                              :ARG0 (c3 / country
                                    :mod (c4 / crucial)
                                    :mod (g2 / geopolitics)
                                    :poss p)

                                    :domain c3)))

                  :ARG1 p)
            :quant (m / multiple
                  :op1 (t2 / temporal-quantity
                        :quant 1
                        :unit (d / day)))))

(p / possible-01
      :ARG1 (b / belong-01
            :ARG0 (y / you)

                  :op1 (r / religion
                        :mod (a / any))
                  :op2 (c / caste
                        :mod (a2 / any))
                  :op3 (c2 / creed

# ::alignments 2-1.1 8-1.1.1 6-1.1.2 5-1.1.2.1 4-1.1.2.2 11-1.1.2.3 14-1.1.2.3.1 13-1.1.2.3.1.1 8-1.1.2.3.2 10-1.1.2.3.2.1 18-1.2 32-1.2.2 28-1.2.2.2 46-1.2.2.2.2.1 40-1.2.2.2.2.1.1.1.r 40-1.2.2.2.2.1.1.1 43-1.2.2.2.2.1.1.2 44-1.2.2.2.2.1.2 50-1.2.2.2.2.1.2 49-1.2.2.2.2.1.2.1 52-1.2.2.2.2.1.2.2 24-1.2.2.2.3.r 22-1.2.2.2.3 21-1.2.2.2.3.1 
# ::snt We are starting with this fundamental principle that we are all citizens of one state... You will find that in due course of time, Hindus will cease to be Hindus and Muslims will cease to be Muslims, not in the religious sense  ... but in the political sense as citizens of the state."
(m / multi-sentence
      :snt1 (s / start-01
            :ARG0 (w / we)
            :ARG2 (p / principle
                  :mod (f / fundamental)
                  :mod (t / this)
                  :mod (c / citizen
                        :poss (s2 / state
                              :quant 1)
                        :domain (w2 / we
                              :mod (a / all)))))
      :snt2 (f2 / find-01
            :ARG0 (y / you)
            :ARG1 (a2 / and
                  :op1 (c2 / cease-01
                        :ARG1 (p2 / person
                              :mod (r / religious-group
                                    :name (n / name
                                          :op1 "Hindu"))
                              :domain (p3 / person
                                    :mod r)))
                  :op2 (c3 / cease-01
                        :ARG1 (p4 / person
                              :mod (r2 / religious-group
                                    :name (n2 / name
                                          :op1 "Muslim"))
                              :domain p3)
                        :ARG1-of (c4 / cause-01
                              :ARG0 (c5 / contrast-01
                                    :ARG1 (s3 / sense
                                          :polarity -
                                          :mod (r3 / religion))
                                    :ARG2 (s4 / sense
                                          :mod (p5 / politics)
                                          :domain (c6 / citizen
                                                :poss s2
                                                :domain p4))))
                        :time (c7 / course
                              :mod (d / due))))))

# ::id 1317a869.8 ::snt-type body

# ::alignments 1-1 2-1.2 5-1.3 4-1.3.1 20-1.3.2 8-1.3.2.1 11-1.3.2.2 10-1.3.2.2.1 13-1.3.2.3 15-1.3.2.3.1 18-1.3.2.3.1.1 17-1.3.2.3.1.1.1 16-1.3.2.3.1.1.2 21-1.3.2.4 24-1.3.2.4.1 25-1.3.2.4.1.1 26-1.3.2.4.1.2.r

      :ARG1 (t / they)
      :ARG2 (b / ballistic)

            :mod (l / little)
            :example (o / or
                  :op1 (f / flag
                        :mod (c / country
                              :name (n / name
                                    :op1 "Mexico")))
                  :op2 (t3 / truck
                        :mod (t4 / taco))
                  :op3 (l2 / library
                        :ARG0-of (o2 / offer-01

                                    :mod (b2 / bilingual))))

                                    :name (n2 / name
                                          :op1 "English")))))))

                        :ARG0-of (h2 / have-rel-role-91

                              :ARG2 (g / grandfather)))

                        :op1 (c / country
                              :name (n / name
                                    :op1 "Ireland"))
                        :op2 (c2 / country
                              :name (n2 / name
                                    :op1 "Germany"))
                        :op3 (c3 / country
                              :name (n3 / name
                                    :op1 "Italy"))
                        :op4 (c4 / country
                              :name (n4 / name
                                    :op1 "Poland")))
                  :direction (o2 / off)
                  :destination (b / boat))
            :op2 (a2 / and
                  :op1 (d / draped-01
                        :ARG0 p
                        :ARG1 p

                              :mod (c5 / country
                                    :name (n5 / name
                                          :op1 "America")))
                        :time (ii2 / immediate))

                        :ARG0 p
                        :ARG1 (t / tongue
                              :mod (n6 / native)
                              :poss p))
                  :op3 (a3 / abandon-01
                        :ARG0 p
                        :ARG1 (c6 / culture
                              :poss p))

                        :ARG0 p
                        :ARG1 (m / music

                                    :op2 "Doodle"
                                    :op3 "Dandy"))))))

                                                      :ARG2 p3)

# ::id 1317a869.24 ::snt-type body
# ::tok Far from discovering that recent immigrants are ducking the assimilation process , the study found that `` immigrants of the past quarter-century have assimilated more rapidly than their counterparts of a century ago , even though they are more distinct from the native population upon arrival . ''
# ::alignments 14-1 13-1.1 9-1.2 5-1.2.1 5-1.2.1.1.r 5-1.2.1.1 34-1.2.2.r 35-1.2.2.r 2-1.2.2 45-1.2.2.2 1-1.2.2.3.2.r 24-1.2.2.3.2 28-1.2.2.3.3 32-1.2.2.3.3.2 32-1.2.2.3.3.2.1 30-1.2.2.3.3.2.2.1 31-1.2.2.3.3.2.2.2 25-1.2.3.r 25-1.2.3 40-1.2.3.1.2.r 38-1.2.3.1.2 39-1.3.1 7-1.3.1.2 17-1.3.1.2.1 17-1.3.1.2.1.1.r 17-1.3.1.2.1.1 4-1.3.1.2.1.2 10-1.3.1.2.2 23-1.3.1.2.2.1 
# ::snt Far from discovering that recent immigrants are ducking the assimilation process, the study found that "immigrants of the past quarter-century have assimilated more rapidly than their counterparts of a century ago, even though they are more distinct from the native population upon arrival."
(f / find-01
      :ARG0 (s / study)
      :ARG1 (a / assimilate-01
            :ARG0 (p / person
                  :ARG0-of (ii / immigrate-01)
                  :time (b / before
                        :op1 (n / now)
                        :quant (t / temporal-quantity
                              :quant 0.5
                              :unit (c / century))))
            :concession (d / distinct
                  :domain p
                  :time (a2 / arrive-01
                        :ARG1 p)
                  :ARG2-of (h / have-degree-91
                        :ARG1 p
                        :ARG3 (m / more)
                        :ARG4 (c2 / counterpart
                              :poss p
                              :time (b2 / before
                                    :op1 (n2 / now)
                                    :quant (t2 / temporal-quantity
                                          :quant 1
                                          :unit (c3 / century))))))
            :manner (r / rapid
                  :ARG2-of (h2 / have-degree-91
                        :ARG1 a
                        :ARG3 (m2 / more)
                        :ARG4 c2)))
      :location (r2 / relative-position
            :op1 (d2 / discover-01
                  :ARG0 s
                  :ARG1 (d3 / duck-01
                        :ARG0 (p2 / person
                              :ARG0-of (ii2 / immigrate-01)
                              :time (r3 / recent))
                        :ARG1 (p3 / process-02
                              :ARG1 (a3 / assimilate-01)))
                  :quant (f2 / far))))

# ::id 1317a869.28 ::snt-type body
# ::tok And Canadian and Indian immigrants have low levels of civic assimilation , since few of them become citizens .
# ::alignments 5-1.1 2-1.1.1 4-1.1.1.1 4-1.1.1.1.1.r 4-1.1.1.1.1 7-1.1.2 6-1.1.2.1 10-1.1.2.1.1 9-1.1.2.1.1.2 16-1.1.3 16-1.1.3.1 17-1.1.3.1.1 14-1.1.3.1.1.1 13-1.1.3.1.1.1.2 
# ::snt And Canadian and Indian immigrants have low levels of civic assimilation, since few of them become citizens.
(a / and
      :op2 (h / have-03
            :ARG0 (a2 / and
                  :op1 (p / person
                        :ARG0-of (ii / immigrate-01
                              :ARG2 (c / country
                                    :name (n / name
                                          :op1 "Canada"))))
                  :op2 (p2 / person
                        :ARG0-of (ii2 / immigrate-01
                              :ARG2 (c2 / country
                                    :name (n2 / name
                                          :op1 "India")))))
            :ARG1 (l / level
                  :ARG1-of (l2 / low-04
                        :ARG2 (a3 / assimilate-01
                              :ARG1 a2
                              :ARG2 (c3 / civic))))
            :ARG1-of (c4 / cause-01
                  :ARG0 (b / become-01
                        :ARG1 (c5 / citizen
                              :ARG2-of (ii3 / include-91
                                    :ARG1 a2
                                    :ARG3 (f / few)))))))

      :ARG2 (g / good-02
            :ARG1 (n / news)
            :mod (o / overall)))

# ::id 1317a869.30 ::snt-type body

      :ARG0 (c / country
            :name (n / name
                  :op1 "America"))
      :ARG1 (j / job
            :ARG1-of (e / excellent-02)
            :topic (a / assimilate-01
                  :ARG0 c
                  :ARG1 (p / person
                        :ARG0-of (ii / immigrate-01))))
      :mod (s / still)
      :time (a2 / after
            :quant (m / more-than
                  :op1 (t / temporal-quantity
                        :quant 200
                        :unit (y / year)))))

            :polarity -

                  :mod (p / particular)))
      :ARG2 (e / even-if
            :op1 (t / try-01

                  :ARG1 (r / resist-01
                        :ARG0 g
                        :ARG1 (p2 / process-02)))))

      :domain (t / that))

                  :name (n / name
                        :op1 "Ruben"
                        :op2 "Navarrette"
                        :op3 "Jr."))

                  :mod (e / editorial)
                  :part-of (n2 / newspaper
                        :name (n3 / name
                              :op1 "San"
                              :op2 "Diego"
                              :op3 "Union-Tribune")))
            :ARG2 (m / member))
      :op2 (c / columnist
            :ARG1-of (s / syndicate-01
                  :location (n4 / nation))
            :domain p))

# ::id 1317a869.37 ::snt-type body

(r / read-01
      :mode imperative
      :ARG0 (y / you)
      :ARG1 (c / column
            :poss (h / he))
      :location (h2 / here))

# ::snt-type date [signifies start of new document]

# ::id 25b7adf8.1 ::snt-type summary
# ::tok Ruben Navarrette shares what Hispanic readers are saying to him .

(s / share-01
      :ARG0 (p / person
            :name (n / name
                  :op1 "Ruben"
                  :op2 "Navarrette"))
      :ARG1 (t / thing
            :ARG1-of (s2 / say-01
                  :ARG0 (p2 / person
                        :ARG0-of (r / read-01)
                        :mod (e / ethnic-group
                              :name (n2 / name
                                    :op1 "Hispanic")))
                  :ARG2 p)))

                  :ARG1-of (s / say-01
                        :ARG0 h))
            :topic (d / debate-01
                  :ARG1 (ii / immigrate-01))
            :mod (u / ugly)))

      :ARG1 (a / and

            :op2 (r / racism)

                  :quant 2
                  :ARG0-of (d / distasteful-00
                        :ARG1-of (f / find-02
                              :ARG0 (t / they))))))

                        :mod (c3 / country
                              :name (n2 / name
                                    :op1 "Mexico"))))

                                    :mod c3
                                    :domain ii)))))
      :medium (c7 / comment-01
            :ARG0 ii
            :time (r / recent)))

# ::id 25b7adf8.8 ::snt-type body
# ::tok After nearly 20 years of writing opinions and insisting that I do n't speak for all Hispanics , in recent months , I 've heard from hundreds of Hispanics who -- appreciative of my middle-ground approach to the immigration issue -- insist that I can speak for them anytime .
# ::alignments 24-1 33-1.1 8-1.2 26-1.2.1.2.1 31-1.2.1.3 31-1.2.1.3.1 39-1.2.1.3.1.2 38-1.2.1.3.1.2.1 34-1.2.1.3.1.3.1 44-1.2.2 13-1.2.2.1 48-1.2.2.1.3 20-1.4 19-1.4.1 7-1.5.1 5-1.5.1.1 6-1.5.1.1.2 6-1.5.1.1.2.1.r 6-1.5.1.1.2.1 41-1.5.1.2 45-1.5.1.2.2 11-1.5.1.2.2.1.r 12-1.5.1.2.2.1.r 12-1.5.1.2.2.1 15-1.5.1.2.2.3.2 14-1.5.1.3.r 1-1.5.1.3 2-1.5.1.3.1.1 3-1.5.1.3.1.2 
# ::snt After nearly 20 years of writing opinions and insisting that I don't speak for all Hispanics, in recent months, I've heard from hundreds of Hispanics who -- appreciative of my middle-ground approach to the immigration issue -- insist that I can speak for them anytime.
(h / hear-01
      :ARG0 (ii / i)
      :ARG1 (ii2 / insist-01
            :ARG0 (p / person
                  :mod (e / ethnic-group
                        :name (n / name
                              :op1 "Hispanic"))
                  :quant (m / multiple
                        :op1 100)
                  :ARG0-of (a / appreciate-02
                        :ARG1 (a2 / approach-02
                              :ARG0 ii
                              :ARG1 (ii3 / issue-02
                                    :ARG0 (ii4 / immigrate-01))
                              :mod (g / ground
                                    :mod (m2 / middle)))))
            :ARG1 (p2 / possible-01
                  :ARG1 (s / speak-01
                        :ARG0 ii
                        :ARG2 p
                        :time (a3 / anytime))))
      :ARG2 p
      :time (m3 / month
            :mod (r / recent))
      :time (a4 / after
            :op1 (a5 / and
                  :op1 (w / write-01
                        :ARG0 ii
                        :ARG1 (t / thing
                              :ARG1-of (o / opine-01)))
                  :op2 (ii5 / insist-01
                        :ARG0 ii
                        :ARG1 (s2 / speak-01
                              :polarity -
                              :ARG0 ii
                              :ARG2 (p3 / person
                                    :mod e
                                    :mod (a6 / all))))
                  :duration (n2 / nearly
                        :op1 (t2 / temporal-quantity
                              :quant 20
                              :unit (y / year))))))

# ::snt The topic: the immigration debate and what she called a wave of hate sweeping the land -- one that isn't limited to illegal immigrants, but which is now affecting all Hispanics regardless of where they were born, what language they speak or what flag they salute.
(t / topic
      :domain (a / and
            :op1 (d / debate-01
                  :ARG1 (ii / immigrate-01))
            :op2 (w / wave-04
                  :ARG1 (h / hate-01)
                  :ARG1-of (s / sweep-02
                        :ARG2 (l / land))
                  :ARG1-of (l2 / limit-01
                        :polarity -
                        :ARG2 (p / person
                              :ARG0-of (ii2 / immigrate-01)
                              :ARG1-of (l3 / legal-02
                                    :polarity -))
                        :ARG1-of (c / contrast-01
                              :ARG2 (a2 / affect-01
                                    :ARG0 w

                                          :mod (e / ethnic-group

                                                      :op1 "Hispanic"))

                                          :ARG2 (o / or
                                                :op1 (l4 / location
                                                      :location-of (b / bear-02
                                                            :ARG1 p2))

                                                      :ARG3-of (s2 / speak-01

                                                      :ARG1-of (s3 / salute-01
                                                            :ARG0 p2))))

                        :ARG0 (s4 / she)))))

# ::id b82546b7.4 ::snt-type body
# ::tok My love for University of Memphis basketball is completely irrational .
# ::alignments 9-1.1.r 9-1.1 1-1.2 6-1.2.2 4-1.2.2.1.1.2 8-1.3 
# ::snt My love for University of Memphis basketball is completely irrational.
(r / rational
      :polarity -
      :domain (l / love-01
            :ARG0 (ii / i)
            :ARG1 (b / basketball
                  :mod (u / university
                        :name (n / name
                              :op1 "University"
                              :op2 "of"
                              :op3 "Memphis"))))
      :ARG1-of (c / complete-02))

# ::id b82546b7.5 ::snt-type body
# ::tok I never went to school there and have no affiliation with the university .
# ::alignments 6-1 2-1.1 4-1.1.3 3-1.1.4.r 5-1.1.4 1-1.1.5 9-1.2 8-1.2.1.r 8-1.2.1 12-1.2.3 
# ::snt I never went to school there and have no affiliation with the university.
(a / and
      :op1 (g / go-02
            :polarity -
            :ARG0 (ii / i)
            :ARG1 (s / school)
            :ARG4 (t / there)
            :time (e / ever))
      :op2 (a2 / affiliate-01
            :polarity -
            :ARG1 ii
            :ARG2 (u / university)))

      :ARG2 (b / bleed-01
            :ARG1 (ii / i)
            :ARG2 (b2 / blue
                  :mod (t / tiger))))

(a / and
      :op1 (t / take-01
            :ARG0 (p / person
                  :ARG0-of (h / have-rel-role-91
                        :ARG1 (ii / i)
                        :ARG2 (d / dad)))
            :ARG1 (a2 / and
                  :op1 (p2 / person
                        :ARG0-of (h2 / have-rel-role-91
                              :ARG1 ii
                              :ARG2 (b / brother)))
                  :op2 ii)
            :ARG3 (g / game
                  :location (c / city
                        :name (n / name
                              :op1 "Memphis")))
            :time (u / use-03)
            :time (k / kid
                  :domain ii))
      :op2 (h3 / hook-01
            :ARG1 ii
            :ARG2 g
            :time (s / since
                  :op1 t)
            :time (e / ever)))

            :decade 1980))

            :ARG3 (p4 / picture)))

                        :degree (q / quite))

      :ARG0 (p / person

                  :op1 "Denzel"
                  :op2 "Washington"))

                  :time-of (ii / issue-02
                        :quant (m / many)))))

# ::alignments 4-1 3-1.1 5-1.2.1.1 6-1.2.1.2 
# ::snt It is the crisis affecting our children: .
(a / affect-01
      :ARG0 (c / crisis)
      :ARG1 (p / person
            :ARG0-of (h / have-rel-role-91
                  :ARG1 (w / we)
                  :ARG2 (c2 / child))))

# ::id 9eccfcc2.12 ::snt-type body
# ::tok  Nearly 30 percent of this year 's freshman class will drop out of high school , according to the National Center for Education Statistics .
# ::alignments 22-1.1.1.3 11-1.2 3-1.2.1 17-1.2.1.1.r 13-1.2.1.1 9-1.2.1.1.1 8-1.2.1.1.1.1 6-1.2.1.1.1.2 5-1.2.1.1.1.2.1 3-1.2.1.1.2.1 2-1.2.1.1.2.1.1 14-1.2.2

      :ARG0 (p / publication
            :name (n / name
                  :op1 "National"
                  :op2 "Center"
                  :op3 "for"
                  :op4 "Education"
                  :op5 "Statistics"))
      :ARG1 (d / drop-out-04
            :ARG0 (p2 / person
                  :ARG1-of (ii / include-91
                        :ARG2 (c / class
                              :mod (f / freshman)
                              :time (y / year
                                    :mod (t / this)))
                        :ARG3 (n2 / nearly
                              :op1 (p3 / percentage-entity
                                    :value 30))))
            :ARG1 (h / high-school)))

# ::id 9eccfcc2.13 ::snt-type body

(j / jump-01
      :ARG1 (n / number

            :quant (s / some)))

# ::id 9eccfcc2.14 ::snt-type body
# ::tok  The obesity rate for our kids has gone up by as much as 300 percent since 1980 , according to the National Center for Health Statistics , triggering a host of health-related problems , from diabetes to heart disease .
# ::alignments 4-1.1.1.3 3-1.2.1 2-1.2.1.1 6-1.2.1.2 5-1.2.1.2.1.r 5-1.2.1.2.1 13-1.2.2 15-1.2.2.1 14-1.2.2.1.1 16-1.2.3 17-1.2.3.1.1 28-1.2.4 30-1.2.4.1 31-1.2.4.1.1.r 33-1.2.4.1.1 19-1.2.4.1.1.1.r 32-1.2.4.1.1.1.1 36-1.2.4.1.1.2 38-1.2.4.1.1.3.2 39-1.2.4.1.1.3.3 
# ::snt  The obesity rate for our kids has gone up by as much as 300 percent since 1980, according to the National Center for Health Statistics, triggering a host of health-related problems, from diabetes to heart disease.
(s / say-01
      :ARG0 (o / organization
            :name (n / name
                  :op1 "National"
                  :op2 "Center"
                  :op3 "for"
                  :op4 "Health"
                  :op5 "Statistics"))
      :ARG1 (ii / increase-01
            :ARG1 (r / rate
                  :mod (o2 / obesity)
                  :mod (k / kid
                        :poss (w / we)))
            :ARG2 (a / as-much-as
                  :op1 (p / percentage-entity
                        :value 300))
            :time (s2 / since
                  :op1 (d / date-entity
                        :year 1980))
            :ARG0-of (t / trigger-01
                  :ARG1 (h / host
                        :consist-of (p2 / problem
                              :ARG1-of (r2 / relate-01
                                    :ARG2 (h2 / health))
                              :example (d2 / diabetes)
                              :example (d3 / disease
                                    :name n
                                    :op1 "heart"
                                    :op2 "disease"))))))

# ::id 9eccfcc2.15 ::snt-type body
# ::tok  Young people account for more than 20 percent of violent crimes in the United States , according to statistics cited by Duke University 's Center for Child and Family Policy .
# ::alignments 20-1.1.1 4-1.1.1.1.1.2 24-1.1.1.1.1.3 28-1.1.1.1.1.4 17-1.2 8-1.2.1 11-1.2.2 9-1.2.2.1 11-1.2.2.1.1 10-1.2.2.1.1.1 12-1.2.2.1.1.2.r 19-1.2.2.1.1.2.1.2 5-1.2.2.1.2 8-1.2.2.1.2.1 7-1.2.2.1.2.1.1 
# ::snt  Young people account for more than 20 percent of violent crimes in the United States, according to statistics cited by Duke University's Center for Child and Family Policy.
(s / say-01
      :ARG0 (s2 / statistics
            :ARG1-of (c / cite-01
                  :ARG0 (o / organization
                        :name (n / name
                              :op1 "Center"
                              :op2 "for"
                              :op3 "Child"
                              :op4 "and"
                              :op5 "Family"
                              :op6 "Policy")
                        :part-of (u / university
                              :name (n2 / name
                                    :op1 "Duke")))))
      :ARG1 (a / account-01
            :ARG0 (p / person
                  :mod (y / young))
            :ARG1 (c2 / crime-02
                  :ARG1-of (ii / include-91
                        :ARG2 (c3 / crime-02
                              :mod (v / violent)
                              :location (c4 / country
                                    :name (n3 / name
                                          :op1 "United"
                                          :op2 "States")))
                        :ARG3 (m / more-than
                              :op1 (p2 / percentage-entity
                                    :value 20))))))

                        :mod (s / school)))))

# ::alignments 18-1 18-1.1 17-1.1.1 20-1.1.2 4-1.1.2.1.r 2-1.1.2.1 14-1.1.2.1.2 33-1.1.2.1.2.2 35-1.1.2.1.2.2.2 40-1.1.2.1.2.2.2.1.1 39-1.1.2.1.2.2.2.1.1.1 36-1.1.2.1.2.3 26-1.1.2.1.2.3.1.r 26-1.1.2.1.2.3.1 30-1.1.2.1.2.3.1 28-1.1.2.1.2.3.2 3-1.2.1 16-1.2.1.1 8-1.2.1.1.2 7-1.2.1.1.2.1 11-1.2.1.1.3 10-1.2.1.1.3.1 13-1.2.1.1.4.1

(h / have-condition-91
      :ARG1 (h2 / have-03
            :ARG0 (y / you)
            :ARG1 (g / generation
                  :consist-of (p / person
                        :mod (c / country
                              :name (n / name
                                    :op1 "America"))
                        :ARG1-of (p2 / prepare-02
                              :polarity -
                              :ARG2 (m / meet-01
                                    :ARG0 g
                                    :ARG1 (c2 / challenge-01
                                          :ARG1-of (p3 / pose-01
                                                :ARG0 (w / world
                                                      :mod (c3 / complex)))))
                              :ARG1-of (p4 / possible-01
                                    :polarity -
                                    :mod (ii / indeed))))))
      :ARG2 (f / factor-01
            :ARG1 (p5 / pattern-01
                  :ARG1 (a / and
                        :op1 (p6 / poor)
                        :op2 (a2 / activity-06
                              :ARG1 (g2 / gang))
                        :op3 (a3 / abuse-02
                              :ARG1 (d / drug))

                  :ARG1-of (p7 / persist-01))))

# ::id 8a25813d.28 ::snt-type body

# ::alignments 1-1.2 13-1.3 7-1.3.1 2-1.3.1.1.1.2 4-1.3.1.2 4-1.3.1.2.1.r 4-1.3.1.2.1 9-1.3.1.4 9-1.3.1.4.1.r 9-1.3.1.4.1 8-1.3.1.4.1.1 9-1.3.1.4.1.2 
# ::snt Ask your friends, neighbors, co-workers and church members who they are voting for.
(a / ask-01
      :mode imperative
      :ARG0 (y / you)
      :ARG1 (v / vote-01
            :ARG0 (a2 / and
                  :op1 (p / person
                        :ARG0-of (h / have-rel-role-91
                              :ARG1 y
                              :ARG2 (f / friend)))
                  :op2 (p2 / person
                        :ARG1-of (n / neighbor-01
                              :ARG2 y))
                  :op3 (p3 / person
                        :ARG3-of (w / work-01
                              :ARG0 y))
                  :op4 (p4 / person
                        :ARG0-of (h2 / have-org-role-91
                              :ARG1 (c / church)
                              :ARG2 (m / member)))))
      :ARG2 a2)

(p / press-01
      :mode imperative

      :ARG1 (t / they)
      :time (g / give-01
            :ARG0 t
            :ARG1 (l / line
                  :mod (p2 / possible-01

                                    :part (f / finger))
                              :ARG1 f
                              :ARG2 (ii2 / it))
                        :ARG1-of (r / real-04)))
            :ARG2 y))

            :medium (r2 / radio)
            :poss ii2)

            :ARG4 (w / while)))

# ::id b8a1fa60.23 ::snt-type body

                                          :op1 "Palin"))

                              :purpose (r / rebuke-01
                                    :ARG0 p2
                                    :ARG1 (c3 / comment-01

                                                      :ARG1 p2))

                                                :op1 (c4 / call-01

                                                            :part-of (c5 / crowd))
                                                      :ARG1 (p4 / person
                                                            :name (n3 / name
                                                                  :op1 "Obama")

                                                      :ARG2 (t2 / terrorist))

                                                            :prep-with h3))
                                                :op3 (s5 / suggest-01

            :ARG2 p2))

# ::id b8a1fa60.42 ::snt-type body

# ::alignments 30-1 7-1.2.3 22-1.2.6.1.2 18-1.2.6.3 27-1.2.7 27-1.2.7.1.r 27-1.2.7.1 26-1.2.7.1.2 28-1.2.8 34-1.3 39-1.3.2.1.2

                              :op1 "Barack"
                              :op2 "Obama"))

                        :name (n5 / name

                  :ARG0 u)

      :ARG2 (p2 / publication

                  :op2 "Press"))
      :time (d / date-entity
            :weekday (t2 / thursday)))

# ::id ee44eade.33 ::snt-type body
# ::tok Colleges most often determine the utility of admission test scores by assessing how well they predict first-year grades .

# ::snt Colleges most often determine the utility of admission test scores by assessing how well they predict first-year grades.

      :ARG0 (c / college)
      :ARG1 (u / utility
            :poss (s / score-01
                  :ARG2 (a / admit-02)
                  :ARG3 (t / test-01)))
      :ARG2 (a2 / assess-01
            :ARG0 c
            :ARG1 (g / good-03
                  :ARG1 c
                  :ARG2 (p / predict-01
                        :ARG0 c
                        :ARG1 (g2 / grade
                              :mod (y / year
                                    :ord (o / ordinal-entity
                                          :value 1))))))
      :frequency (o2 / often
            :ARG2-of (h / have-degree-91
                  :ARG1 d
                  :ARG3 (m / most))))

# ::tok Attack ads broadcast in recent months have twisted the truth , lied about personal background , taken statements out of context , and clearly sought to manipulate voter sentiments .
# ::alignments 22-1 7-1.1 2-1.1.1.2 5-1.1.1.2.1 4-1.1.1.2.1.1 9-1.1.2 11-1.2 14-1.2.2 13-1.2.2.1 16-1.3 17-1.3.2 17-1.3.2.1.r 17-1.3.2.1 20-1.3.3 26-1.4.2 28-1.4.2.2 27-1.4.2.2.1 27-1.4.2.2.1.1.r 27-1.4.2.2.1.1 23-1.4.3 
# ::snt Attack ads broadcast in recent months have twisted the truth, lied about personal background, taken statements out of context, and clearly sought to manipulate voter sentiments.
(a / and
      :op1 (t / twist-01
            :ARG0 (a2 / advertise-01
                  :ARG0-of (a3 / attack-01)
                  :ARG1-of (b / broadcast-01
                        :time (m / month
                              :mod (r / recent))))
            :ARG1 (t2 / truth))
      :op2 (l / lie-08
            :ARG0 a2
            :ARG3 (b2 / background
                  :ARG1-of (p / personal-02)))
      :op3 (t3 / take-out-11
            :ARG0 a2
            :ARG1 (t4 / thing
                  :ARG1-of (s / state-01))
            :source (c / context))
      :op4 (s2 / seek-01
            :ARG0 a2
            :ARG1 (m2 / manipulate-02
                  :ARG0 a2
                  :ARG1 (s3 / sentiment
                        :poss (p2 / person
                              :ARG0-of (v / vote-01))))
            :ARG1-of (c2 / clear-06)))

            :op1 (c / counter)))

            :poss m))

      :ARG0 (h / he)
      :ARG1 (p / pledge-01
            :ARG0 (p2 / person
                  :ARG0-of (h2 / have-org-role-91
                        :ARG2 (p3 / president))
                  :ARG1-of (n / new-01))

                  :op1 (c / close-01
                        :ARG0 p2
                        :ARG1 (f / facility
                              :name (n2 / name
                                    :op1 "Guantanamo")))
                  :op2 (e / end-01
                        :ARG0 p2
                        :ARG1 (t / torture-01)))))

# ::id 3893e210.8 ::snt-type body
# ::tok Those strikes happen to be the three strongest predictors that enter into the equations used by political scientists to predict who will win an election : an unpopular incumbent president ( in this case , the most unpopular in the history of polling ) , an economic downturn ( in this case an understatement ) , and an unpopular war .
# ::alignments 8-1.1 1-1.1.1 9-1.1.1.1 7-1.2 32-1.4 6-1.4.1 10-1.4.2 13-1.4.2.1 14-1.4.2.1.1 17-1.4.2.1.1.1 16-1.4.2.1.1.1.1 19-1.4.2.1.1.2 22-1.4.2.1.1.2.2 22-1.4.2.1.1.2.2.1.r 22-1.4.2.1.1.2.2.1 24-1.4.2.1.1.2.2.1.1 56-1.4.3.1 29-1.4.3.1.1.1.1 28-1.4.3.1.1.2 37-1.4.3.1.1.3.1.r 36-1.4.3.1.1.4.2 40-1.4.3.1.1.4.3 42-1.4.3.1.1.4.3.1 51-1.4.3.1.1.4.4 53-1.4.3.1.1.4.4.2 47-1.4.3.2 46-1.4.3.2.1 59-1.4.3.3 58-1.4.3.3.1.1.r 
# ::snt Those strikes happen to be the three strongest predictors that enter into the equations used by political scientists to predict who will win an election: an unpopular incumbent president (in this case, the most unpopular in the history of polling), an economic downturn (in this case an understatement), and an unpopular war.

      :ARG1 (p / predict-01
            :ARG0 (s / strike-01
                  :mod (t / that)))
      :ARG2 (s2 / strong-02
            :ARG1 p)
      :ARG3 (m / most)
      :ARG5 (t2 / thing
            :quant 3
            :ARG0-of (e / enter-01
                  :ARG1 (e2 / equation
                        :ARG1-of (u / use-01

                                    :mod (p2 / politics))
                              :ARG2 (p3 / predict-01
                                    :ARG0 s3
                                    :ARG1 (p4 / person
                                          :ARG0-of (w / win-01
                                                :ARG2 (e3 / elect-01)))))))

                  :ARG2 (a / and
                        :op1 (p5 / person
                              :ARG0-of (h2 / have-org-role-91
                                    :ARG2 (p6 / president))
                              :ARG1-of (ii / incumbency-01)
                              :ARG1-of (p7 / popular-02
                                    :polarity -)
                              :ARG1-of (h3 / have-degree-91

                                          :ARG1 p5)

                                          :mod (p9 / poll-01))
                                    :mod (c / case-04
                                          :ARG1 c
                                          :ARG1 (u2 / understatement)))))
                  :op2 (d / downturn
                        :mod (e4 / economy))
                  :op3 (w2 / war-01
                        :ARG1-of (p10 / popular-02
                              :polarity -)))))

# ::alignments 12-1.1 14-1.1.2 17-1.1.2.2 16-1.1.2.2.1 19-1.1.2.2.2 20-1.1.2.2.2.1.r 22-1.1.2.2.2.1 20-1.1.3.r 11-1.1.3 4-1.1.3.1 5-1.1.3.1.1.2 6-1.1.3.1.2.r 8-1.1.3.1.2 
# ::snt And in the last few weeks of the campaign, Obama finally began to control the four stories that matter in an election: .
(a / and
      :op2 (b / begin-01
            :ARG0 (p / person
                  :name (n / name
                        :op1 "Obama"))
            :ARG1 (c / control-01
                  :ARG0 p
                  :ARG1 (s / story
                        :quant 4
                        :ARG1-of (m / matter-01
                              :time (e / elect-01))))
            :time (f / final
                  :op1 (f2 / few
                        :op1 (t / temporal-quantity
                              :quant 1
                              :unit (w / week))
                        :duration-of (c2 / campaign-01)))))

# ::id 3893e210.20 ::snt-type body
# ::tok 1. the story you tell about your yourself ( that he was the candidate of change , fleshing out what he meant by change ) ; .
# ::alignments 4-1 0-1.1.r 0-1.1 3-1.2 2-1.3 5-1.3.1.r 14-1.3.2.r 13-1.3.2 15-1.3.2.1 19-1.3.2.2.r 20-1.3.2.2 17-1.3.2.3 21-1.3.2.3.1 21-1.3.2.3.1.1.r 21-1.3.2.3.1.1 23-1.3.2.3.1.1.2 
# ::snt 1. the story you tell about your yourself (that he was the candidate of change, fleshing out what he meant by change); .
(t / tell-01
      :li 1
      :ARG0 (y / you)
      :ARG1 (s / story
            :topic y
            :consist-of (c / candidate
                  :ARG0-of (c2 / change-01)
                  :domain (h / he)
                  :ARG0-of (f / fleshing-out-02
                        :ARG1 (t2 / thing
                              :ARG2-of (m / mean-01
                                    :ARG0 h
                                    :ARG1 (c3 / change-01)))))))

# ::id 3893e210.21 ::snt-type body
# ::tok 2. the story you tell about your opponent ( that McCain was four more years of Bush ) ; .
# ::alignments 2-1 0-1.1.r 0-1.1 4-1.2 3-1.2.1 6-1.2.1 5-1.2.2.r 7-1.2.2 7-1.2.2.1.r 7-1.2.2.1 15-1.3.r 12-1.3.2.1 14-1.3.2.2 13-1.3.2.3 
# ::snt 2. the story you tell about your opponent (that McCain was four more years of Bush); .
(s / story
      :li 2
      :ARG1-of (t / tell-01
            :ARG0 (y / you)
            :topic (p / person
                  :ARG0-of (o / oppose-01
                        :ARG1 y)))
      :consist-of (p2 / person
            :name (n / name
                  :op1 "Bush")
            :duration (t2 / temporal-quantity
                  :quant 4
                  :unit (y2 / year)
                  :mod (m / more))
            :domain (p3 / person
                  :name (n2 / name
                        :op1 "McCain"))))

# ::id 3893e210.22 ::snt-type body
# ::tok 3. the story the other candidate is telling about himself ( McCain the maverick , which Obama countered by citing McCain 's proud proclamation that he had voted with Bush over 90 percent of the time and parrying , `` That 's not a maverick , that 's a sidekick '' ) ; and .
# ::alignments 0-1.1.r 0-1.1 2-1.2 7-1.2.1 5-1.2.1.1 4-1.2.1.1.1 33-1.2.1.1.2.r 13-1.2.2.1.2 17-1.2.3 36-1.2.3.2 19-1.2.3.2.1 22-1.2.3.2.1.2 23-1.2.3.2.1.2 27-1.2.3.2.1.2.2 35-1.2.3.2.1.2.2.3.r 30-1.2.3.2.1.2.2.3 32-1.2.3.2.1.2.2.3.1 31-1.2.3.2.1.2.2.3.1.1 43-1.2.3.2.1.2.3 37-1.2.3.2.2 44-1.2.3.2.2.3.1 42-1.2.3.2.2.3.1.1.r 42-1.2.3.2.2.3.1.1 49-1.2.3.2.2.3.2 
# ::snt 3. the story the other candidate is telling about himself (McCain the maverick, which Obama countered by citing McCain's proud proclamation that he had voted with Bush over 90 percent of the time and parrying, "That's not a maverick, that's a sidekick"); and .
(a / and
      :li 3
      :op1 (s / story
            :ARG1-of (t / tell-01
                  :ARG0 (c / candidate
                        :mod (o / other)
                        :topic-of t))
            :ARG1-of (m / mean-01
                  :ARG2 (p / person
                        :name (n / name
                              :op1 "McCain")
                        :mod (m2 / maverick)))
            :ARG1-of (c2 / counter-01
                  :ARG0 (p2 / person
                        :name (n2 / name
                              :op1 "Obama"))
                  :ARG2 (a2 / and
                        :op1 (c3 / cite-01
                              :ARG0 p2
                              :ARG1 (p3 / proclaim-01
                                    :ARG0 p
                                    :ARG1 (v / vote-01
                                          :ARG0 p
                                          :ARG1 (p4 / person
                                                :name (n3 / name
                                                      :op1 "Bush"))
                                          :time (o2 / over
                                                :op1 (p5 / percentage-entity
                                                      :value 90)))
                                    :ARG2-of (p6 / pride-01
                                          :ARG0 p)))
                        :op2 (p7 / parry-01
                              :ARG0 p2
                              :ARG1 p3
                              :ARG2 (c4 / contrast-01
                                    :ARG1 (m3 / maverick
                                          :polarity -
                                          :domain p)
                                    :ARG2 (s2 / sidekick
                                          :domain p)))))))

# ::id 3893e210.23 ::snt-type body
# ::tok 4. the story McCain was telling about Obama ( that he lacked the experience and judgment to lead , which Obama countered with his steadiness in the face of the Wall Street meltdown and his strong , steady performances in the debates ) .
# ::alignments 2-1 0-1.1.r 0-1.1 5-1.2 6-1.3.r 28-1.4.r 11-1.4 14-1.4.2 13-1.4.2.1 15-1.4.2.2 16-1.4.3.r 17-1.4.3 21-1.4.4 33-1.4.4.2 24-1.4.4.2.1 27-1.4.4.2.1.2 32-1.4.4.2.1.2.2 25-1.4.4.2.1.2.2.1.r 38-1.4.4.2.2 35-1.4.4.2.2.2 37-1.4.4.2.2.3 41-1.4.4.2.2.4 
# ::snt 4. the story McCain was telling about Obama (that he lacked the experience and judgment to lead, which Obama countered with his steadiness in the face of the Wall Street meltdown and his strong, steady performances in the debates).
(s / story
      :li 4
      :ARG1-of (t / tell-01
            :ARG0 (p / person
                  :name (n / name
                        :op1 "McCain")))
      :topic (p2 / person
            :name (n2 / name
                  :op1 "Obama"))
      :consist-of (l / lack-01
            :ARG0 p2
            :ARG1 (a / and
                  :op1 (e / experience-01
                        :ARG0 p2)
                  :op2 (j / judge-01
                        :ARG0 p2))
            :purpose (l2 / lead-02
                  :ARG0 p2)
            :ARG1-of (c / counter-01
                  :ARG0 p2
                  :ARG2 (a2 / and
                        :op1 (s2 / steady
                              :domain p2
                              :condition (f / face-01
                                    :ARG0 p2
                                    :ARG1 (m / meltdown
                                          :location (m2 / market-sector
                                                :name (n3 / name
                                                      :op1 "Wall"
                                                      :op2 "Street")))))
                        :op2 (p3 / perform-02
                              :ARG0 p2
                              :ARG1-of (s3 / strong-02)
                              :mod (s4 / steady)
                              :subevent-of (d / debate-01
                                    :ARG0 p2))))))

# ::id 3893e210.24 ::snt-type body
# ::tok Elections are won by candidates who control those four stories and in so doing inspire the electorate and channel their fears ( in this case , fears about the economy trumping all else ) .
# ::alignments 2-1 4-1.1 6-1.1.1 9-1.1.1.1 8-1.1.1.1.1 7-1.1.1.1.2 12-1.1.1.2 10-1.1.1.2.1 14-1.1.1.2.1.1 16-1.1.1.2.1.1.2 18-1.1.1.2.1.2 30-1.1.1.2.1.3.1 20-1.1.1.2.1.3.1.1 26-1.1.1.2.1.3.1.1 27-1.1.1.2.1.3.1.1.1.r 29-1.1.1.2.1.3.1.1.1 31-1.1.1.2.1.3.1.2 32-1.1.1.2.1.3.1.2.1 11-1.1.1.2.1.3.1.3.r 24-1.1.1.2.1.3.1.3 23-1.1.1.2.1.3.1.3.1 
# ::snt Elections are won by candidates who control those four stories and in so doing inspire the electorate and channel their fears (in this case, fears about the economy trumping all else).
(w / win-01
      :ARG0 (c / candidate
            :ARG0-of (c2 / control-01
                  :ARG1 (s / story
                        :quant 4
                        :mod (t / that))
                  :ARG0-of (c3 / cause-01
                        :ARG1 (a / and
                              :op1 (ii / inspire-01
                                    :ARG0 c
                                    :ARG1 (e / electorate)
                                    :ARG2 (f / fear-01
                                          :ARG0 e))
                              :op2 (c4 / channel-01
                                    :ARG0 c
                                    :ARG1 f)
                              :ARG1-of (m / mean-01
                                    :ARG2 (t2 / trump-01
                                          :ARG0 (f2 / fear-01
                                                :topic (e2 / economy))
                                          :ARG1 (a2 / all
                                                :mod (e3 / else))
                                          :prep-in (c5 / case-04
                                                :ARG1 (t3 / this))))))))
      :ARG2 (e4 / elect-01))

# ::id 3893e210.25 ::snt-type body
# ::tok Going forward , Obama needs to find his way as a leader between the excesses of the `` permanent campaign , '' in which a president remains in campaign mode throughout his presidency -- taken to its extreme under George W. Bush , who allowed his political strategist , Karl Rove , an inordinate role in crafting policies rather than just figuring out how to talk with the public about them -- and Obama 's more natural predilection to talk like a law professor .
# ::alignments 4-1 6-1.2 8-1.2.2 63-1.2.2.1.r 11-1.2.2.1 7-1.2.2.2.r 12-1.2.3 14-1.2.3.1 31-1.2.3.1.1.r 19-1.2.3.1.1 18-1.2.3.1.1.1 26-1.2.3.1.1.2 25-1.2.3.1.1.2.1.1.1 29-1.2.3.1.1.2.2 28-1.2.3.1.1.2.2.1 30-1.2.3.1.1.2.3 34-1.2.3.1.1.2.4 37-1.2.3.1.1.2.4.1 38-1.2.3.1.1.2.4.2 44-1.2.3.1.1.2.4.2.1.2 54-1.2.3.1.1.2.4.2.1.2.1 69-1.2.3.1.1.2.4.2.1.2.1.2.r 56-1.2.3.1.1.2.4.2.1.2.1.2 57-1.2.3.1.1.2.4.2.1.2.1.2.1 61-1.2.3.1.1.2.4.2.1.2.1.2.2.1 65-1.2.3.1.1.2.4.2.1.2.1.2.2.1.2 68-1.2.3.1.1.2.4.2.1.2.1.2.2.1.2.2 77-1.2.3.2 76-1.2.3.2.1.1 75-1.2.3.2.1.2 74-1.2.3.2.2.r 79-1.2.3.2.3 80-1.2.3.2.3.2 83-1.2.3.2.3.2.1 82-1.2.3.2.3.2.1.1 1-1.3 
# ::snt Going forward, Obama needs to find his way as a leader between the excesses of the "permanent campaign," in which a president remains in campaign mode throughout his presidency -- taken to its extreme under George W. Bush, who allowed his political strategist, Karl Rove, an inordinate role in crafting policies rather than just figuring out how to talk with the public about them -- and Obama's more natural predilection to talk like a law professor.
(n / need-01
      :ARG0 (p / person
            :name (n2 / name
                  :op1 "Obama"))
      :ARG1 (f / find-01
            :ARG0 p
            :ARG1 (w / way
                  :manner-of (l / lead-02
                        :ARG0 p)
                  :poss p)
            :ARG2 (b / between
                  :op1 (e / excess
                        :poss (c / campaign-01
                              :mod (p2 / permanent)
                              :time-of (r / remain-01
                                    :ARG1 (p3 / person
                                          :ARG0-of (h / have-org-role-91
                                                :ARG2 (p4 / president)))
                                    :ARG3 (m / mode
                                          :mod (c2 / campaign-01))
                                    :duration (t / throughout
                                          :op1 (h2 / have-org-role-91
                                                :ARG0 p3
                                                :ARG2 p4))
                                    :ARG1-of (t2 / take-03
                                          :ARG2 (e2 / extreme)
                                          :time (u / under
                                                :op1 (p5 / person
                                                      :name (n3 / name
                                                            :op1 "George"
                                                            :op2 "W."
                                                            :op3 "Bush")
                                                      :ARG0-of (a / allow-01
                                                            :ARG1 (r2 / role
                                                                  :mod (ii / inordinate)
                                                                  :topic (c3 / craft-01
                                                                        :ARG1 (p6 / policy-01)
                                                                        :ARG1-of (ii2 / instead-of-91
                                                                              :ARG2 (f2 / figure-out-05
                                                                                    :ARG0 p5
                                                                                    :ARG1 (t3 / talk-01
                                                                                          :ARG0 p5
                                                                                          :ARG2 (p7 / public)
                                                                                          :ARG3 p6))))))))))))
                  :op2 (p8 / predilection
                        :ARG1-of (h3 / have-degree-91
                              :ARG2 (n4 / natural-03
                                    :ARG1 p8)
                              :ARG3 (m2 / more))
                        :poss p
                        :mod (t4 / talk-01
                              :ARG0 p
                              :ARG1-of (r3 / resemble-01
                                    :ARG2 (p9 / professor
                                          :mod (l2 / law)))))))
      :time (f3 / forward))

# ::id 3893e210.26 ::snt-type body
# ::tok What Democrats learned from this election is that if their candidate thinks like a professor but inspires like a preacher , they can have their cake and eat it , too .
# ::alignments 2-1 26-1.2.1 23-1.2.1.1 25-1.2.1.1.2 27-1.2.1.2 30-1.2.1.2.3 8-1.2.2.r 15-1.2.2 11-1.2.2.1 10-1.2.2.1.1 17-1.2.2.1.2 14-1.2.2.1.2.1 16-1.2.2.2 19-1.2.2.2.2.1 19-1.2.2.2.2.1.1.r 19-1.2.2.2.2.1.1 5-1.3 
# ::snt What Democrats learned from this election is that if their candidate thinks like a professor but inspires like a preacher, they can have their cake and eat it, too.
(l / learn-01
      :ARG0 (p / political-party
            :name (n / name
                  :op1 "Democrat"))
      :ARG1 (p2 / possible-01
            :ARG1 (a / and
                  :op1 (h / have-06
                        :ARG0 p
                        :ARG1 (c / cake
                              :poss p))
                  :op2 (e / eat-01
                        :ARG0 p
                        :ARG1 c
                        :mod (t / too)))
            :condition (c2 / contrast-01
                  :ARG1 (t2 / think-01
                        :ARG0 (c3 / candidate
                              :poss p)
                        :ARG1-of (r / resemble-01
                              :ARG2 (p3 / professor)))
                  :ARG2 (ii / inspire-01
                        :ARG0 c3
                        :ARG1-of (r2 / resemble-01
                              :ARG2 (p4 / person
                                    :ARG0-of (p5 / preach-01))))))
      :ARG2 (e2 / elect-01
            :mod (t3 / this)))

# ::snt President-elect Obama faces enormous mountains to climb that will require enormous public support.

      :ARG0 (p / person
            :name (n / name
                  :op1 "Obama")
            :ARG1-of (e / elect-01
                  :ARG2 (h / have-org-role-91
                        :ARG0 p
                        :ARG2 (p2 / president))))
      :ARG1 (m / mountain
            :mod (e2 / enormous)
            :ARG1-of (c / climb-01
                  :ARG0 p)
            :ARG0-of (r / require-01
                  :ARG1 (s / support-01
                        :ARG0 (p3 / public)
                        :mod (e3 / enormous)))))

# ::snt He will no doubt pursue the policies he considers best for digging our nation out of some deep ditches, both domestically and internationally.

      :ARG0 (h / he)

            :ARG1-of (c / consider-01
                  :ARG0 h
                  :ARG2 (g / good-04
                        :ARG2 (d / dig-out-03

                                    :poss (w / we))

                                    :ARG1-of (d3 / deep-02)
                                    :quant (s / some)

                                          :op1 (d4 / domestic)
                                          :op2 (ii / international))))
                        :ARG2 n
                        :ARG2-of (h2 / have-degree-91
                              :ARG1 p2
                              :ARG3 (m / most)))))
      :ARG1-of (d5 / doubt-01
            :polarity -))

# ::id 3893e210.29 ::snt-type body
# ::tok But the best policies do n't sell themselves , whether the date is November 3 or January 21 , and the style that led him to the White House -- a calm , thoughtful , steady approach to policy combined with an extraordinary capacity to inspire -- is the same style that will make him an extraordinary leader .
# ::alignments 19-1 6-1.1.1 4-1.1.1.1.r 5-1.1.1.1.r 5-1.1.1.1 3-1.1.1.2 2-1.1.1.2.1.1 15-1.1.1.4.1 14-1.1.1.4.1.1.1 17-1.1.1.4.1.2.1 30-1.1.1.4.1.2.2 21-1.2 49-1.2.1 50-1.2.1.1 53-1.2.1.1.1 23-1.2.1.1.1.1 23-1.2.1.1.1.1.1.r 23-1.2.1.1.1.1.1 42-1.2.1.1.1.1.2 36-1.2.2 38-1.2.2.1 31-1.2.2.2 33-1.2.2.3 35-1.2.2.4 43-1.2.2.5.1 45-1.2.2.5.1.2 57-1.2.3 54-1.2.3.1 44-1.2.3.2.r 
# ::snt But the best policies don't sell themselves, whether the date is November 3 or January 21, and the style that led him to the White House -- a calm, thoughtful, steady approach to policy combined with an extraordinary capacity to inspire -- is the same style that will make him an extraordinary leader.
(a / and
      :op1 (c / contrast-01
            :ARG2 (s / sell-01
                  :polarity -
                  :ARG0 (p / policy-01
                        :ARG1-of (h / have-degree-91
                              :ARG2 (g / good-02
                                    :ARG1 p)
                              :ARG3 (m / most)))
                  :ARG1 p
                  :ARG1-of (r / regardless-91
                        :ARG2 (o / or
                              :op1 (d / date-entity
                                    :day 3
                                    :month 11)
                              :op2 (d2 / date-entity
                                    :day 21
                                    :month 1)))))
      :op2 (s2 / style
            :ARG1-of (s3 / same-01
                  :ARG2 (s4 / style
                        :ARG0-of (m2 / make-02
                              :ARG1 (p2 / person
                                    :ARG0-of (l / lead-02)
                                    :mod (e / extraordinary)))))
            :domain (a2 / approach-02
                  :ARG1 (p3 / policy-01)
                  :ARG1-of (c2 / calm-03)
                  :mod (t / thoughtful)
                  :ARG1-of (s5 / steady-01)
                  :ARG0-of (h2 / have-03
                        :ARG1 (c3 / capable-01
                              :ARG1 p2
                              :ARG2 (ii / inspire-01
                                    :ARG0 p2)
                              :mod e)))
            :ARG0-of (l2 / lead-01
                  :ARG1 (h3 / he)
                  :ARG4 (g2 / government-organization
                        :name (n / name
                              :op1 "White"
                              :op2 "House")))))

# ::id 464a6206.1 ::snt-type summary

            :time (d / depress-02)))

                        :ARG1 (p2 / problem))
                  :time (u / until
                        :op1 (d / day
                              :time-of (ii / inaugurate-01)))))
      :ARG2 (p3 / person
            :name (n / name
                  :op1 "Eichengreen")))

# ::id 464a6206.5 ::snt-type body

                              :mod (s / stock))))))

# ::alignments 3-1 11-1.2.1 9-1.2.1.1 8-1.2.1.1.1 10-1.2.1.1.2 6-1.2.1.2 9-1.2.1.3 14-1.2.1.3.1 17-1.2.1.3.1.1.1 20-1.2.1.3.1.2.1 23-1.2.1.3.2 26-1.2.1.3.2.1.1.1 29-1.2.1.3.2.2.1 21-1.2.2 37-1.2.2 36-1.2.2.1 34-1.2.2.1.2.1 31-1.2.2.2.1.r 32-1.2.2.3

      :ARG1 (e / event
            :name (n / name
                  :op1 "Great"
                  :op2 "Depression"))

                                    :year 1926))

                                    :mod (t / tech
                                          :ARG1-of (h2 / high-02)))
                              :time (d2 / date-entity
                                    :year 1929))))
            :op2 (a4 / and
                  :op1 (n2 / neglect-01

                              :ARG0-of (l / legislate-01))

# ::snt-type date [signifies start of new document]

# ::id 6071da75.1 ::snt-type summary
# ::tok David Craig : I 've been battling for marriage equality for gays since 1990 .
# ::alignments 6-1.2 9-1.2.2 8-1.2.2.1 11-1.2.2.1.1 11-1.2.2.1.1.1.r 11-1.2.2.1.1.1 12-1.2.3 13-1.2.3.1.1 
# ::snt David Craig: I've been battling for marriage equality for gays since 1990 .
(s / say-01
      :ARG0 (p / person
            :name (n / name
                  :op1 "David"
                  :op2 "Craig"))
      :ARG1 (b / battle-01
            :ARG0 p
            :ARG2 (e / equal-01
                  :ARG1 (m / marry-01
                        :ARG1 (p2 / person
                              :ARG1-of (g / gay-01))))
            :time (s2 / since
                  :op1 (d / date-entity
                        :year 1990))))

# ::snt He says civil unions don't provide same level of rights and benefits as marriage .

      :ARG0 (h / he)
      :ARG1 (p / provide-01
            :polarity -
            :ARG0 (u / union-02
                  :mod (c / civil))
            :ARG1 (l / level
                  :ARG1-of (s2 / same-01
                        :ARG2 (m / marry-01))
                  :consist-of (a / and
                        :op1 (r / right-05)
                        :op2 (b / benefit-01)))))

            :year 1990)

            :op1 (h / have-06
                  :ARG0 (a2 / and
                        :op1 (p / person
                              :name (n / name
                                    :op1 "Brian"
                                    :op2 "Binder")
                              :ARG0-of (h2 / have-rel-role-91
                                    :ARG1 ii
                                    :ARG2 (p2 / partner)))
                        :op2 ii)
                  :ARG1 (c / ceremony
                        :mod (c2 / commit-01)))))
